title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. The Social Security Act allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a serious health risk to enrollees or reduces available plans significantly. The Social Security Act permits the Secretary to postpone the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a significant health risk to enrollees or leads to a notable decrease in available plans in the affected area. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a health risk or reduces available plans in the area. The Secretary may audit the organization's books to make this determination. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if an adequate provider network is established to provide equal insurance coverage. The Secretary may also renegotiate the contract if needed. The Secretary may delay termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if a provider network is established for equal coverage. Negotiation for a new contract can occur during this period to ensure beneficiaries are not negatively impacted. SEC. 3. EXTENSION OF INITIAL MEDICARE+CHOICE CONTRACT PERIOD TO 3 YEARS. Amends the Social Security Act to require Medicare+Choice contracts to have a minimum term of 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare+Choice organizations to provide written notice 120 days before contract termination, including descriptions of alternative benefit options. The Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare+Choice organizations to provide written notice 120 days before contract termination, including descriptions of alternative benefit options and contact information for local social service agencies. This amendment applies to termination notices provided after the enactment of the Act.
